results.title: Mr. Rossi in Venice
results.creator_credit: Bruno Bozzetto and Bruno Bozzetto Films
results.brief_description: Mr Rossi finds himself in Venice - not the Venice of postcards, but of polluted canals, rotten buildings, and overcrowded steamboats. Eager to impress a pretty tourist, Mr Rossi takes up the fight against the disease that is destroying the city. But it is like tilting a windmill. Mr Rosi is defeated before an enemy too big to conquer - pollution. Animation by Giorgio Valenti.

results.title: Mr. Neal Is Entitled to Be an Agitator
results.creator_credit: Daryl Dellora, Sue Maslin and Film Art Doco Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: This film takes its title from the judgement handed down by Lionel Murphy in favour of a Queensland Aboriginal activist. Judge Lionel Murphy (1922-1986), noted for legal reforms such as the Family Law Act and Trade Practices Act, was the most senior judicial figure in the modern history of the Commonwealth to be charged with a criminal offence. The film examines the events surrounding this controversial case with Murphy battling to retain his position on the High Court during the last years of his life. In a wider sense, the film considers some of the more fundamental issues about Australian law, the role of the police and security and surveillance in Australia.

results.title: Mr. & Mrs. Edgehill
results.brief_description: Lady Cynthia is a woman of wealth and position, but she is touched and amazed by the love and devotion of Mr and Mrs Edgehill feel for one another. What is it that makes this ordinary couple so content with their life - even on a remote and desolate South sea Island? The screen play is written by T R Bowen, from the original work by Noel Coward. Rated: G

results.title: Mr Wrong
results.creator_credit: Gaylene Preston, Robin Laing and Preston-Laing Productions
results.brief_description: In this psychological thriller, the heroine, Meg, believes her Mark II Jaguar is haunted by its previous owner who was murdered by a hitchhiker. She tries to sell the car but it refuses to unlock for men. Stalked by the hitchhiker and threatened by other men she encounters, she uses her heightened fear as a spur to assertive self-defence. While deploying the conventions of the thriller to build a feeling of terror the film subverts this genre to examine the threat of sexual violence towards women and the myth that a ‘Mr Right’ will ultimately step into save them. Its at times comic tone and fairy-tale quality balance the seriousness of the underlying feminist message. It was the first New Zealand film made by a female producer/director team. Based on the story by Elizabeth Jane Howard. Cast includes Heather Bolton, David Letch and Margaret Umbers. Reference: “New Zealand Film 1912-1996”. eds. Helen Martin and Sam Edwards Oxford University Press 1997, p. 118.

results.title: Mr Wasinski's song
results.creator_credit: Aidan Fennessy, Sandi Austin and Cinemedia
results.brief_description: While visiting an ear doctor Mr Wasinski discovers that his deafness is linked to a frightening childhood experience. During his consultation the doctor discovers gauze buried deep within his ear canal and upon its removal Mr. Wasinski becomes vulnerable to a barrage of repressed childhood memories. Having lived as a child in Poland during Nazi occupation Mr. Wasinski’s deafness marks the loss of his innocence as a child when separated from his parents during a desperate attempt to escape. The vivid memories suppressed with the aid of his deafness prove a challenge to an aging man who seeks distance from his childhood experiences. Stars Bruce Kerr as Mr Wasinski.

results.title: Mr Symbol man
results.creator_credit: Bruce Moir, Tom Daly, Film Australia and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Blissymbols are giving children without speech a joyous new means of communication. A Canadian/Australian co-production, This film tells the story of a remarkable man, Australian Charles K. Bliss, who invented a symbol language (pictographs) originally as a means of overcoming the barrier of differing languages, and then found that it has an even greater, more rewarding application when used with speech-handicapped children. This is witnessed in Toronto and Montreal, where the Blissymbols are being used. (Awards: Melbourne; San Francisco; Sydney; Mexico) See “Symbol boy” (Title code 307141) for animated cartoon embodying the complete Blissymbols.

results.title: Mr Stuart answers the question
results.creator_credit: Jarvia Guillard, United States. Dept. of Commerce and U.S.A Department of Agriculture
results.brief_description: A retail sales training film showing how Mr Stuart, the owner of a typical small retail store, found an answer to increased competition in a buyer’s market and how he corrected bad selling habits which had developed in his store.

results.title: Mr Squiggle and friends Bandywallop
results.creator_credit: Julia Kalytis, Pam Verrall, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC Video
results.brief_description: Mr Squiggle and all his favourite friends from Bandywallop join in the fun in three complete episodes. There’s Roxanne of course, Bill Steamshovel Gus the snail, Merv Wallop and his nephew, Wayne. Episodes include: “Hen Pen”, “Ten Lane Highway”, “Singing Salesman”. Rated: G

results.title: Mr Squiggle and Friends
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Julia Kalytis and Pam Verrall
results.brief_description: Mr. Squiggle and his friends have been entertaining Australian children for almost 30 years on ABC television. Now he lives in Bandywallop and is just as much fun as ever. This first video of Mr. Squiggle has all his favourite friends including Roxanne, sharing adventures with Bill and Gus, Merv Wallop and his nephew Wayne. Episodes include : “Squiggle”, “Settlers’ Week”, “The Knapsack”. Rated: G
